Expectation1: Take scheduled breaks and adhere to work hours
Situation1: An automated compliance system flags any minute of unscheduled downtime for possible disciplinary action.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: Several other volunteers can easily cover the first part of the shift if someone shows up a little late.
Story: I glanced at the clock on my monitor, my headset still warm from the last call. My volunteer shift at the food pantry started in fifteen minutes, but my telemarketing break wasn’t scheduled for another half hour. The compliance system blinked a warning—any unscheduled downtime would be flagged, and I’d already been cautioned once this month. My supervisor’s words echoed in my mind: “Stick to your schedule, or it’ll go on your record.” But I’d promised the pantry coordinator I’d be there on time, and I hated the thought of letting her down, even if the other volunteers could cover for a bit. My stomach twisted as I weighed the risk of disciplinary action against the guilt of not keeping my word. I stared at the “Log Out” button, my finger hovering, caught between the rigid demands of my job and the flexible, yet meaningful, commitment I’d made as a volunteer.
